participating-org.narrative: Human Rights Research and Advocacy Consortium

The Human Rights Research and Advocacy Consortium (HRRAC) was formed early 2003 and brings together eight Afghan and six international organisations committed to promoting peace and human rights in Afghanistan. The member organisations contribute a wealth of experience, from the fields of humanitarian relief, rehabilitation, human rights, women's rights, peace promotion, research and advocacy. They include some of the most experienced and respected agencies working in Afghanistan, and their extensive programme experiencesgives HRRAC an unrivalled access to communities. HRRAC is therefore a unique initiative for Afghanistan, and for other countries emerging from conflict and insecurity.
HRRAC engages in research, training and collective and pro-activeadvocacy activities on human rights in Afghanistan. The first phases of HRRAC (2003-2005) were co-funded by USIP (United States Institute for Peace) and (Oxfam) Novib with contributions of the consortium members. The third and fourth phases (2005-2007 and2007-2011) were funded by Oxfam Novib with member contributions.
HRRAC intends to influence the development and implementation of policies, to promote peace, security and human rights, by motivating people to voice their opinions, concerns and priorities, and give their input to human rights-based policy changes. HRRAC focuses on issues related to social (mainly education), economic- and political rights. The different projects concerned research to generate information on what Afghans think aboutkey human rights issues, including security rights, political rights, and the right to quality education in the country. HRRAC intends to collect the opinions and voices of Afghans from all parts of the country, without any distinction in sex, gender, education, occupation, ethnicity or location. The research findings will be communicated to the government, donor agencies, civil society organisations, and participating communities from all over the country. It will also use this research to advocate for positive policy changes.
During the four earlier phases HRRAC has published a number of documents on education, civic education, disarmament, governance issues and women rights. These publications were widely spread and appreciated.
In the last years HRRAC’s core programme addressed the political and development environment. These were optimum for advocacy activities (young democracy/parliament, decentralisation in development, strong donor attention for good governance,education, etc.). HRRAC gathered strengths and opportunities of the members in a joint advocacy approach, which functioned as an important feed back to many national NGOs. This joint/network approach also has contributed in avoiding “re-invention of the wheel”, especially with active/effective participation of AREU and ACBAR. This puts HRRAC in a rather unique position.
Since 2010 HRRAC is concentrating its efforts in the following: The right to political participation (with a special emphasis on women’s participation) Access to justice Rights to livelihood and economic security Freedom of expression The right to peace and physical security The rightto education Countering traditional practices that are incompatible with human rights
Considering the current political environment in the country, women’s political and public rights will continue to be a prioritized objective of the organization during the coming years. This forms the main subject for HRRAC’s current partnership with Oxfam Novib, which aims at strengtheningof the enabling environment for equitable and independent participation of women in national and provincial peace- and reconciliation processes at the national and provincial level via public action. This will be tackled by a three fold strategy consisting of the components: Research, advocacy and awareness-raising.
